ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Ruiz Food Products, Inc. is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program. This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration equipment at the Ruiz Food Products, Inc. facility. 

It is the policy of Ruiz Food Products, Inc. to ensure that controls are in place to prevent possible releases of ammonia. If such a release does occur, the facility's emergency response personnel are trained to control and mitigate the effects of the release. The facility has coordinated emergency response activities with the Region 5 LEPC and the Dinuba Fire Department, who provide additional emergency response expertise. 

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
 
Ruiz Food Products, Inc's primary activity is frozen food manufacturing. Located at 501 South Alta Avenue in Dinuba, California, the facility prepares, stores, and ships frozen food products. Ammonia is the only RMP-regulated substance at the facility, and it is used to provide refrigeration for the preparation and cold storage of various food products. The maximum inventory of ammonia at the facility is approximately 75,000 pounds. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS 

The Ruiz Food Products, Inc. facility is in full compliance with EPA's accidental release prevention requirements as defined in 40 CFR Part 68, the requirements for the California Accidental Release Prevention program (CalARP), the OSHA PSM requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119, and the EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place at the Dinuba facility. 

Process Safety Information 
Ruiz Food Products, Inc. maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes

the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment specifications associated with the ammonia refrigeration equipment and process. 

Process Hazards Analysis 
The facility has conducted comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the ammonia system are identified and effectively controlled. Checklists and the HAZOP methodology were used to carry out the process hazards analyses. The studies were undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations, and will be revalidated at least every five years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. 

Operating Procedures 
To further ensure that activities are safely conducted in the ammonia system, Ruiz Food Products, Inc. has developed written operating procedures to supplement the current on-the-job operator training. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operation, normal shutdown and startup, and emergency shutdown and startup. This information is regularly reviewed and readily accessible to operators involved in the processes. 

Training 
Ruiz Food Products, Inc. has an on-the-job training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating process equipment are competent in the operating procedures associated with this equipment. Written procedures are used to enhance the on-the-job training. Refresher training is provided at least every three years. All training is documented and validated. 

Mechanical Integrity 
Ruiz Food Products, Inc. has a written maintenance program in place for preventative maintenance of all ammonia equipment to ensure continuing reliable and safe operation. Equipment maintained under this program include pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, compressors and pumps. System maintenance is completed only by qualified personnel with training in maintenance practices, including in-hous

e personnel and contractors as needed. Specialized training is provided as needed to ensure maintenance personnel are fully qualified. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. 

Management of Change 
Written procedures are followed at Ruiz Food Products, Inc. to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. This ensures that process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification. 

Pre-startup Reviews 
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Ruiz Food Products, Inc. These written review procedures formally ensure that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation. 

Compliance Audits 
Ruiz Foods conducts audits on a regular basis to verify that the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented. These audits will be carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits will be undertaken in a safe and prompt manner. 

Incident Investigation 
Ruiz Food Products, Inc. promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could have resulted in a release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from occurring under similar situations. All reports are retained for a minimum of five years. 

Employee Participation 
Ruiz Food Products, Inc. believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort and has developed a written plan to implement this philosophy. Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning a

ccident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, facility employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, particularly information resulting from process hazard analyses. 

Hot Work Permitting 
Ruiz Food Products, Inc. has developed a permitting procedure for all hot work conducted in the vicinity of the ammonia equipment. It documents that appropriate fire prevention measures have been implemented, and defines the work dates and scope of work to be performed. The permit is kept on site until completion of the work. 

Contractor Safety 
On occasion, the facility hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is carried out. Ruiz Food Products, Inc. has a strict policy of informing the contractors of any known potential hazards related the contractor's work and the processes within the facility. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur. 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
 
An investigation into Ruiz Food Products, Inc.'s accident history revealed that there have been two ammonia incidents over the past five years (June 2004 to June 2009), one of which that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds.  Details of the leaks are included below:

December 2004 Incident

The facility had an ammonia release from one of the coils in the Freezers on December 26, 2004.  The pipe threads at the inlet of the coil connection had ruptured.  Approximately five pounds of ammonia was released from the system.  An investigation into the incident revealed that the point where the pipe had ruptured was the weakest part of the coil assembly as a result of fourteen years of daily operation and constant thermal expansion.  Vibrations caused by the evaporator fans and motors also contrib

uted to the weakening of the pipe.   The pipe that had ruptured was cleaned and welded, and pipe supports for the liquid and suction lines were also installed.  There were no injuries or offsite impacts resulting from this release.

April 2009 Incident

On April 23, 2009, the facility had an ammonia release from the pressure relief valve installed on one of the condensers.  An investigation into the incident revealed that the relief valve was faulty.  Although the relief valve was rated at 250 psig, it actuated at 152 psig.  Operators stopped the release by turning the three-way valve on the dual relief valve assembly.  Approximately 2,500 pounds of ammonia was released from the system.  Emergency responders, including the Dinuba Fire Department, were notified.  California OES, National Response Center, OSHA, and Tulare County were notified as well.  Nine employees were transported to the hospital and received treatment for ammonia inhalation.  

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
 
Ruiz Food Products, Inc. has developed a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas. 

The facility's emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced to ensure they are properly functioning.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within processes that would require a modified emergency response. 

The Ruiz Food Products, Inc. facility coordinates its emergency response plan with the Region 5 LEPC and the Dinuba Fire Department. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following changes are planned or are already underway to improve the level of safety within our plant. These include: 
-	Ongoing evaluation of recommendations made during the recent

Process Hazards Analysis and Three-Year Compliance Audit.
-	Further improvements to operating and maintenance procedures. 
-	Additional training to increase the number of employees with emergency response capabilities
